Issue Title: WCAG 2.5.2 (Level A) : Actions must not trigger on press or touch down
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. â€¦Activate any CKEditor element that has a "balloon" interface.
2. â€¦Click anywhere outside of the balloon interface to dismiss it
3. â€¦The balloon interface is dismissed on key/press down, rather than mouse up or finger-lift.

### âœ”ï¸ Expected result

The balloon interface is dismissed on mouse up or finger-lift.

### âŒ Actual result

The balloon interface is dismissed on key/press down, rather than mouse up or finger-lift.

### Background
This constitutes a failure a Level A Success Criterion as documented in https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/pointer-cancellation.html

The specific failure is documented in https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/failures/F101 :

> The objective of this Failure is to describe situations where:
> 
>     Controls are set to activate functionality on the down-event of a pointer;
>     No further mechanism to abort or undo is available;
>     The up-event does not reverse the outcome of the activation;
>     It is not essential for the functionality to execute and complete on the down-event.

### Proposed resolution
Change the behavior so that balloons are dismissed on the "up" event, rather than the "down" event.
acr_note: Users who tap or press keys to interact with the CKEditor balloon may inadvertently dismiss it at the moment of the press, causing loss of context or unsaved content and hindering task completion.
dev_note: 1. **Use native semantics** â€“ Wrap the balloon in a `<dialog>` element (or `<div role="dialog" aria-modal="true">` if `<dialog>` cannot be used) and give it a `tabindex="0"` so it can receive focus.
thread_tldr: A user reports that a CKEditor balloon interface is dismissed on mouse/pressâ€‘down instead of mouseâ€‘up, violating WCAGâ€¯2.2 pointerâ€‘cancellation guidance. No further discussion or resolution comments are present in the thread.
thread_problem: The balloon interface is dismissed on key/press down rather than mouse up or finger lift, which triggers a failure to the WCAGâ€¯2.2 pointerâ€‘cancellation requirement. This causes accidental activation for users who may not intend to dismiss the balloon, particularly those using assistive technologies or nonâ€‘mouse input.
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
thread_links: - [WCAGâ€¯2.2 Success Criterion 2.5.2 â€“ Pointer Cancellation](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/pointer-cancellation.html): Defines the requirement that actions must not trigger on press or touch down. - [WCAGâ€¯2.2 Failure F101 â€“ Activation on Downâ€‘Event](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/failures/F101): Describes failure scenarios for activation on down-event.

Issue Title: Link (edit mode) - Bookmarks - not accessible with screen reader
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/link.html
2. Insert Link (use button or shorcut)
3. Select "Bookmarks" in the balloon panel

### âœ”ï¸ Expected result

The screen reader should announce:

- List
- with 2 entries
- Heritage button

### âŒ Actual result

The Screen reader announces:

- List
- Heritage button

### â“ Possible solution

- Number of elements = 0: Display only an informational text (already implemented).
- Number of elements = 1: Both `<ul>` and `<li>` have the attribute `role="presentation"` â†’ In screen readers, the button is announced without a list structure.
- Number of elements > 1: `<ul>` and all `<li>` elements have no `role="presentation"` attribute â†’ In screen readers, the list is announced correctly as a list.

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

* Browser: Edge 138.0.3351.65
* OS: Windows 11 (10.0.22631 Build 22631)
* Screenrader: JAWS 2024
* First affected CKEditor version: v46.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: see demo page

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The screen reader fails to announce the single bookmark entry in the CKEditor link editor. When only one bookmark is present, the list and list item are given `role="presentation"`, causing assistive technologies to treat them as nonâ€‘semantic elements and omit the item from the accessibility tree. Users relying on screen readers therefore cannot hear that a bookmark list exists or navigate to the bookmark.
thread_tldr: The CKEditorâ€¯5 link balloon panel fails to announce the list of bookmark entries to JAWS 2024, so users only hear â€œListâ€ and the â€œHeritage button.â€ No followâ€‘up or resolution has been recorded.
thread_problem: In CKEditorâ€¯5, when the Link button is used and the â€œBookmarksâ€ option is selected, a screen reader does not announce the list of bookmark items. This omission violates WCAGâ€¯2.2 Success Criterionâ€¯1.3.1 (Info and Relationships) by failing to convey the information that a list of options is available.
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. No further discussion recorded.

Issue Title: Link (edit mode) - new options - not accessible with screen reader
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/link.html
2. Insert Link (use button or shorcut)
3. Navigate to "Bookmarks" with "Tab" key

### âœ”ï¸ Expected result

- The options at the end of the balloon panel should consist only of interactive buttons (no other element types).
- Navigation between these option buttons should be possible only via the Tab key (no arrow-key navigation or other unexpected focus changes).
- When focused (first option), the screen reader should announce: "Bookmarks button"

### âŒ Actual result

- The options at the end of the balloon panel are implemented as unordered list (`<ul>`).
- Navigation between these options is currently possible using the Tab key as well as the Arrow Up and Arrow Down keys.
- When focus is on the first option, the screen reader announces: "List" "Bookmarks button"

### â“ Possible solution

- Hide the list structure from assistive technologies by adding `role="presentation"` to `<ul>` element.
- Remove arrow key (Arrow Up / Arrow Down) navigation between the option buttons so that navigation is only possible via the Tab key.

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

Alternative implementation suggestion â€” if the component is intended to behave like a navigation menu:

- Number of elements = 0: Do not display the area (already implemented).
- Number of elements = 1: Both `<ul>` and `<li>` have the attribute `role="presentation"` â†’ The button is announced by the screen reader without any list structure.
- Number of elements > 1: `<ul>` and all `<li>` elements have no `role="presentation"` attribute â†’ The list is announced by the screen reader as an actual list.
- Navigation to the list should be done via the Tab key.
- Navigation within the list should be possible only via the Arrow Up / Arrow Down keys (not via Tab).
- Pressing Arrow Right should follow the chevron and trigger the selected option.

* Browser: Edge 138.0.3351.65
* OS: Windows 11 (10.0.22631 Build 22631)
* Screenrader: JAWS 2024
* First affected CKEditor version: v46.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: see demo page

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: Users who rely on screen readers hear the extra announcement â€œListâ€ before the first option (â€œBookmarks buttonâ€) because the options are wrapped in an unordered list. This unintended list announcement creates confusion and extra cognitive load, and the use of arrowâ€‘key navigation for the options is inconsistent with the expected tabâ€‘only interaction. The barrier impedes efficient access to the link options, limiting the userâ€™s ability to quickly select and activate the desired option.
thread_tldr: The link edit mode balloon panel in CKEditorâ€¯5 exposes a `<ul>` of options that screen readers announce as â€œListâ€ and allow arrowâ€‘key navigation, which is not expected for buttonâ€‘only controls. No further discussion or resolution has been recorded.
thread_problem: The options at the end of the balloon panel are implemented as an unordered list (`<ul>`) that screen readers announce as â€œListâ€ before the option text, and navigation between options can be performed with both Tab and arrow keys. The expected behavior is that only button elements are present, navigation should be via Tab only, and the screen reader should announce only the button label.
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
thread_links: - [CKEditor Link Feature](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/link.html): Documentation for the link feature in CKEditorâ€¯5. - [WAIâ€‘ARIA presentation role](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/#presentation): Specifies that `role="presentation"` hides structure from assistive technologies. - [MDN Role presentation](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Roles/Presentation_Role): Details on using role presentation to hide layout.

Description: ## ğŸ“ Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any) 1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/bookmarks.html 2. Place cursor before bookmark icon 4. Press the arrow right key ### âœ”ï¸ Expected result - The screen reader braille should ouput the bookmark icon or an alternative text. ### âŒ Actual result - The Screen reader braille output "et" ### â“ Possible solution - The bookmark icon is a decorative graphic and should stay hidden as it is. - Insert a text for screen readers only, e.g. ` ` ## ğŸ“ƒ Other details - The div with class="ck-fake-selection-container" is not linked to the bookmark, but the screen reader accounces the information. * Browser: Edge 138.0.3351.65 * OS: Windows 11 (10.0.22631 Build 22631) * Screenrader: JAWS 2024 * First affected CKEditor version: not shure when it started - seen in v44.3 and later * Installed CKEditor plugins: see demo page --- If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.

thread_tldr: The bookmark icon in CKEditorâ€™s edit mode is announced incorrectly by JAWS 2024â€”screen readers output â€œetâ€ instead of the intended bookmark name or an appropriate hidden state. Only the initial report exists, with no followâ€‘up comments or evidence of a resolution.
thread_problem: In CKEditorâ€™s edit mode the bookmark icon is perceived by screen readers as the nonâ€‘text sequence â€œetâ€ rather than the intended bookmark or a correctly hidden element. The icon lacks a proper accessible name or is not correctly hidden, violating WCAGâ€¯2.2 Success Criterionâ€¯1.1.1 (Nonâ€‘text Content), which requires a text alternative for nonâ€‘text content, and potentially 1.3.1 (Info & Relationships) for conveying accurate information.

Issue Title: Table (edit mode) - not accessible with screen readers
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/tables/tables.html
2. Place cursor above the table
4. Press the arrow down key (the horizontal cursor becomes visible)
5. Press the arrow down key (the table receives focus)
6. Press the Tab key (the first cell receives focus)

### âœ”ï¸ Expected result

- The screen reader user should receive clear infromation about the current position and available actions.

- The screen reader should announce:
   - "insert a line before table <caption text>"
   - "Table with 4 columns and 6 rows"
   - The caption: "Countries that sent their citizen into space"
   - Braille: r1c1 "Country"

The help (Alt+0) should provide a hint that tables can be entered using the"Tab" key.

### âŒ Actual result

- Screen reader output is minimal or unclear:
   - "t"
   - (silence, no output)
   - Braille: r1c1 "Country"

Even when reading the help (Alt+0), the users obtains no guidance on how to enter a table. 


## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

* Browser: Edge 138.0.3351.65
* OS: Windows 11 (10.0.22631 Build 22631)
* Screenrader: JAWS 2024
* First affected CKEditor version: not shure when it started - seen in v44.3 and later
* Installed CKEditor plugins: see demo page

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: Users navigating CKEditor in tableâ€‘edit mode with a screen reader (e.g., JAWS) receive no useful information when the focus moves into a table cell. The screen reader announces only the cell content, and no contextual details about the table, its caption, or available editing actions are announced. This prevents users from understanding the table structure or how to perform table edits.
thread_tldr: CKEditorâ€™s table editing mode does not provide screenâ€‘reader users with sufficient contextual information or navigation guidance, leading to poor announcements when entering table cells. The issue was reported but no subsequent discussion or resolution is recorded.
thread_problem: When a screenâ€‘reader user navigates into CKEditorâ€™s table editing mode, the assistive technology fails to announce the tableâ€™s caption, dimensions, or available actions (e.g., â€œinsert a line before tableâ€¦â€, â€œTable with 4 columns and 6 rowsâ€). This omission prevents users from understanding their current position within the table and how to interact with it. The problem is consistent with WCAGâ€¯2.2 Success Criteriaâ€¯1.3.1 (Meaningful Sequence) and 2.5.2 (Focus Order), which require that content be presented in a logical order and that focus changes be announced appropriately.
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. No further discussion recorded.
thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 â€“ Meaningful Sequence](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#meaningful-sequence): Provides guidance on presenting information in a logical order for assistive technology. - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.5.2 â€“ Focus Order](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#focus-order): Requires that focus navigation follow the logical content sequence.

Issue Title: WCAG 2.2 A: List element `.ck-aria-live-region-list` is empty
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Load the official demo at https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/feature-rich/
2. Inspect the page and look for the `.ck-body-wrapper` beneath the `<body>` element.
3. Inside of the `.ck ck-aria-live-announcer` container are two `aria-live` sections, each containing an `ul` without any items.

### âœ”ï¸ Expected result

The list elements should either be dynamically inserted when there is something to announce or be marked as `aria-hidden` while they do not contain any content.

### âŒ Actual result

The lists exists even if there are zero list items.

This is effectively in violation of [SC 1.3.1](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/info-and-relationships.html) of WCAG 2.2 level A which does not permit empty list elements, since at least one element with the (implicit) `listitem` role is required.

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

* Browser: Chrome 136
* OS: macOS 15.5
* First affected CKEditor version: Unknown
* Installed CKEditor plugins: (Full online demo)

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The page contains an empty `<ul>` inside an `aria-live` region. An empty list violates WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 1.3.1 because lists must contain at least one listitem to convey meaningful information. The presence of the empty list can cause confusion for users of assistive technology, potentially making the live region appear to provide content when it does not.
thread_tldr: An empty `<ul>` inside CKEditorâ€™s live region violates WCAGâ€¯2.2 SCâ€¯1.3.1; only the initial report exists and no followâ€‘up or fix discussion has been recorded.
thread_problem: The CKEditor demoâ€™s live region contains `<ul>` elements that remain empty when there is nothing to announce, which is disallowed by WCAGâ€¯2.2 Levelâ€¯A success criterion SCâ€¯1.3.1 because empty list elements lack at least one `listitem` role.
thread_timeline: #1 : Filed the initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
thread_links: - [WCAGâ€¯2.2 SCâ€¯1.3.1 â€“ Info and Relationships](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/info-and-relationships.html): The success criterion that disallows empty list elements. - [CKEditorâ€¯5 Featureâ€‘Rich Demo](https://ckeditor.com/ckeditor-5/demo/feature-rich/): The page used to reproduce the issue.

Issue Title: Bookmark is not fully accessible
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Use the bookmark tool on static text such as a heading
2. Create a link to that bookmark tool

### âœ”ï¸ Expected result

The static text that is the destination of the link is missing the `tabindex="-1"` attribute. This is necessary to ensure that all assistive technologies tracking focus can be "moved" to that content. 

### âŒ Actual result

It appears as though the `tabindex="-1"` attribute is absent and the link only relies on fragment navigation (via `href` and `id` matching)

Some assistive tech affected are:
* Windows Screen Magnifier with Keyboard Focus tracking turned on: Viewport resets to the top-left corner.
* iOS 18.3.2/ 17.4 VoiceOver & Safari: Focus is reset to the top of the page.
* iOS 17.4 Full Keyboard Access turned on, external keyboard & Safari: Focus is reset to the top of the page.
* JAWS 2023 & Chrome 124: The page structure is unexpectedly announced starting with the page title. Virtual cursor is then set on the correct content navigated.

### â“ Possible solution

When we're linking to static content that doesn't already have the `tabindex` attribute, we should add it for the user.

Use `tabindex="-1"` and not `tabindex="0"` nor `tabindex="1"` (or any positive number) to avoid messing up sequential focus navigation orders.

[Does the @tabable/accessible-links node package help?](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@tabable/accessible-links)

Further reading: https://tab-able.co.uk/inaccessible-links-you-didnt-know-existed/

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

* Browser: Chrome
* OS: Windows
* First affected CKEditor version: 5
* Installed CKEditor plugins: Bookmark, Link

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The page fails to move focus to the bookmarked target when activated, causing screen magnifiers, VoiceOver, and other assistive technologies to reset focus to the top of the page. This prevents users who rely on keyboard or focusâ€‘based navigation from reaching the intended content.
thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditorâ€¯5â€™s bookmark feature does not add a `tabindex="-1"` attribute to target anchors, causing focus reset problems for several assistive technologies. Only three comments have been posted and no fix or update has been recorded, so the barrier remains unresolved.
thread_problem: The CKEditorâ€¯5 bookmark tool creates anchor elements for bookmarks that lack the required `tabindex="-1"` attribute. When users click links to these anchors, screen readers and other assistive technologies lose the current focus context and jump to the top of the page, which violates WCAGâ€¯2.2 Success Criterionâ€¯2.4.7 (Focus Order).
thread_timeline: #1 Witoso: Filed the initial accessibility report with reproduction steps. #2 Comandeer: Referenced a WebKit bug fix on iOS and suggested adding `tabindex="-1"` to anchors. #3 anevins12: Asked whether this is a bug in assistive technology, citing the HTML spec section on focusable areas.
thread_links: - [Bug 179011 on WebKit](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=179011): Reported iOS fix that may address similar behavior. - [HTML spec â€“ Focusable areas](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/interaction.html#focus): Defines what elements are focusable. - [@tabable/accessible-links npm package](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@tabable/accessible-links): Tool that can help ensure links are accessible. - [tabâ€‘able.co.uk â€“ Inaccessible links you didnâ€™t know existed](https://tab-able.co.uk/inaccessible-links-you-didnt-know-existed/): Discussion of focus-related link issues.

Issue Title: Duplicated labels
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide a description of the improvement

Some UI elements have duplicated labels:

* the "Insert via URL" modal dialog has the same label as the URL field it contains (solution: the field could be renamed to "Image URL") ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3f0d41c4-091e-41c3-84e6-07bdf51ff4b1),
* "Paint formatting" has the same label as its menu button (solution: the menu button could be renamed to "Paint formatting options") â€“ the same is true also for the "Highlight", "Insert code block", "Bulleted List", "Numbered List", "Multi-level List", "Track changes".

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

* Browser: Chrome 134.0.6998.166 
* OS: macOS 15.4
* CKEditor version: 44.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: N/A

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: Duplicated labels cause redundant information for users of assistive technology, making it harder to understand the purpose of each control and increasing the cognitive load when navigating the interface.
thread_tldr: The issue reports duplicated labels for several CKEditor UI elements, potentially confusing users of assistive technology. No further discussion or resolution has been recorded; the thread remains in its initial state.
thread_problem: Duplicated labels exist for the â€œInsert via URLâ€ modal dialog and its URL field, as well as for several menu buttons that share the same label as their menu items. This duplication can cause confusion for users who rely on screen readers or other assistive technologies, as distinct interactive elements may be announced with identical or ambiguous names.
thread_timeline: #1 pradeepelamurugu: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

Issue Title: Add `[aria-modal]` to modal dialogs
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide a description of the improvement

Modal dialogs (e.g. "Insert the image") do not have the [`[aria-modal]` attribute](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Reference/Attributes/aria-modal). We could add it to indicate that these modals are, indeed, modal.

Additionally we could also think about adding the [`inert` attribute](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/inert) to the, well, inert part of the page.

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

* Browser: Chrome 134.0.6998.166
* OS: macOs 15.4
* CKEditor version: 44.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: N/A

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The modal dialog (e.g., the â€œInsert the imageâ€ dialog) does not declare `aria-modal="true"`, nor does it isolate the rest of the page with the `inert` attribute. Consequently, assistive technology may not recognize that the dialog is modal, and keyboard focus can move to elements behind the dialog. Users who rely on screen readers or keyboard navigation can inadvertently interact with background content, leading to confusion, lost context, and potential errors.
thread_tldr: The issue proposes adding `aria-modal` (and possibly `inert`) to CKEditor modal dialogs, but no further discussion or resolution has been recorded.
thread_problem: Modal dialogs in CKEditor 44.3.0 lack the `aria-modal` attribute, which could prevent assistive technology users from being informed that the dialog is modal and from being prevented from interacting with background content. This omission may lead to confusion and accidental background interaction.
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
thread_links: - [aria-modal (MDN)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Attributes/aria-modal): MDN reference explaining the attribute and its role in modal dialog accessibility. - [inert (MDN)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/inert): MDN reference explaining the inert attribute for disabling background interaction.

Issue Title: Updating keyboard behavior for menubar
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide a description of the improvement

Currently, if the menubar option is activated via the down arrow, the focus is moved to the first item in the open menu. However, if the same button is activated by the <kbd>space</kbd> key, then the focus stays at it. The [more common pattern](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/menubar/examples/menubar-editor/) is to always move the focus to the first item in the menu, despite the method of opening it.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/59ad442b-5eec-435b-a12b-3eb2a4611a5e

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

* Browser: Chrome 134.0.6998.166
* OS: macOS 15.4
* CKEditor version: 44.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: N/A

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The focus remains on the menubar trigger when the menu is opened with the space key, whereas it moves to the first menu item when opened with the arrow key. This inconsistent focus behavior can confuse keyboardâ€‘only users and prevent them from immediately interacting with the menu options, impairing efficient navigation.
thread_tldr: The issue reports that when a CKEditor menubar is opened with the Space key, focus remains on the menubar button instead of moving to the first menu item, contrary to the recommended behavior in the W3C example. Only the initial report exists; no further discussion or resolution is recorded.
thread_problem: In CKEditor 44.3.0, activating a menubar via the Space key leaves keyboard focus on the menubar toggle, preventing keyboard users from immediately accessing the first menu item. This inconsistent focus behavior hinders efficient navigation for keyboard-only users and deviates from the expected menubar pattern shown in the W3C example.
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
thread_links: - [W3C menubar example](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/menubar/examples/menubar-editor/): Demonstrates the expected keyboard behavior for menubar widgets.

This prevents keyboardâ€‘only users from accessing or activating the image upload functionality, hindering the ability to use the editorâ€™s toolbar.
thread_tldr: A user reports that the split â€œInsert imageâ€ button in CKEditorâ€™s toolbar is omitted from endâ€‘toâ€‘start keyboard navigation, preventing keyboardâ€‘only users from accessing it. No followâ€‘up comments or fixes are present, so the issue remains unresolved.
thread_problem: The â€œInsert imageâ€ split menu button is excluded from the leftâ€‘toâ€‘right keyboard navigation sequence in CKEditorâ€™s toolbar, making it inaccessible to keyboard users. This violates WCAGâ€¯2.2 Success Criterionâ€¯2.1.1 (Keyboard).

Issue Title: Incorrect focus behavior of bookmark and link toolbars
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Go to https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/bookmarks.html
2. Select any bookmark.
3. Click the bookmark toolbar button.

### âœ”ï¸ Expected result

The focus should be moved to the bookmark toolbar.

### âŒ Actual result

The focus stays in the same place.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/af28ebe2-1c31-4dca-81ed-9b8888abe166)

It's extremely confusing for the users of screen readers as it seems like pressing the button does nothing.

The same happens with links and link toolbar (also when using the <kbd>Cmd</kbd>+<kbd>K</kbd> shortcut).

### â“ Possible solution

The focus should be moved to the bookmark/link toolbar when it's shown.

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

* Browser: Chrome 134.0.6998.166 
* OS: macOS 15.4
* First affected CKEditor version: 44.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: `bookmark`, `link`

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The focus does not move to the bookmark or link toolbar after the user activates the toolbar button or shortcut. Keyboardâ€‘only and screenâ€‘reader users therefore remain on the element that triggered the action, making it appear as if the button has no effect and preventing them from accessing the toolbarâ€™s controls. This lack of focus management creates a barrier to efficient navigation and interaction.
thread_tldr: The issue reports that when a bookmark or link toolbar appears in CKEditor 44.3.0 and later, focus is not moved to the toolbar but remains on the button that opened it, confusing screen reader users. The thread currently contains only the initial report with no further discussion.
thread_problem: When the bookmark or link toolbar is displayed, the keyboard focus does not shift to the toolbar; it stays on the button that triggered the dialog. This prevents users of assistive technology from interacting with the newly visible toolbar and violates WCAGâ€¯2.2 Success Criterionâ€¯2.5.3 (Focus Order).
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterion 2.5.3: Focus Order](https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#focus-order): Ensures that focus moves logically to interactive elements. - [CKEditor Bookmark Feature](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/bookmarks.html): Official documentation for the bookmark feature.

Issue Title: Incorrect label for the fullscreen toolbar button
Description:

1. Open a sample with a fullscreen plugin.
2. Check the label of the fullscreen menu button.
3. Click it to enter the fullscreen mode.
4. Check the label of the button.

### âœ”ï¸ Expected result

The label should stay the same.

### âŒ Actual result

Label changes from "Enter fullscreeen mode" to "Leave fullscreen mode".

![The "Enter fullscreen mode" label](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/092f5060-0ecf-4b8a-85d0-ba0c12259deb)
![The "Leave fullscree mode" label](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c46aee3c-4c31-486e-8873-13360c8ea03f)

This behavior is inconsistent with the behavior of any other toggle button (e.g. we have â€œBoldâ€ with on/off state, not â€œBoldâ€ and â€œUnboldâ€; also itâ€™s â€œBoldâ€, not â€œStart boldingâ€).

### â“ Possible solution

The label should be changed to "Fullscreen mode" â€“ the state of the button is already expressed by its styles and `[aria-pressed]` attribute.

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

* OS: macOS 15.4

acr_note: The fullscreen toggle buttonâ€™s accessible name changes from â€œEnter fullscreen modeâ€ to â€œLeave fullscreen modeâ€ when activated, causing confusion for users who rely on consistent names (e.g., screenâ€‘reader users). The dynamic label change can make it difficult to recognize that the same control is being toggled, potentially hindering efficient interaction.
dev_note: 1. Use a native `<button>` element for the toggle to provide builtâ€‘in accessibility support.
thread_tldr: The issue reports that the fullscreen toolbar buttonâ€™s label toggles between â€œEnter fullscreen modeâ€ and â€œLeave fullscreen mode,â€ which is inconsistent with other toggle buttons. No followâ€‘up discussion or resolution has been documented; the issue remains open.
thread_problem: The fullscreen toolbar button changes its visible label when toggled, switching from â€œEnter fullscreen modeâ€ to â€œLeave fullscreen mode.â€ This label change may confuse users because the buttonâ€™s state is already indicated by visual styles and the `aria-pressed` attribute, so the label does not consistently convey the controlâ€™s purpose.

Issue Title: Update how the emoji picker is exposed to the accessibility tree
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide a description of the improvement

Currently, the emoji picker is marked up as `[role=grid]`. We could update it to contain information about the positions of each emoji by [wrapping buttons into `span[role=gridcell]s`](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/grid/examples/layout-grids/). Alternatively, we could reuse our solution from CKEditor 4 (Special Character dialog) and use `[role=listbox]` with `[role=option][aria-posinset][aria-setsize]` children

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

* Browser: 134.0.6998.166 
* OS: macOS 15.4
* CKEditor version: 44.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: `emoji`

---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The emoji picker is exposed to the accessibility tree as a generic `role="grid"` without providing positional information for its cells. This limits the ability of assistive technology users to identify or navigate individual emoji items within the grid, potentially causing confusion and making it difficult to select a specific emoji.
thread_tldr: The issue proposes changing the emoji picker's ARIA markup to provide positional information for each emoji, but the thread contains only the initial report and no further discussion or resolution.
thread_problem: The emoji picker is currently implemented with role="grid" without additional positional context. This can make it difficult for users of assistive technologies to locate and select individual emojis, as the grid cells lack role="gridcell" wrappers or a listbox/option structure with aria-posinset/aria-setsize attributes.
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report.
thread_links: - [ARIA grid pattern example](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/grid/examples/layout-grids/): Demonstrates how to wrap elements in role="gridcell" to provide positional information within a grid.

Issue Title: Incorrect behavior of tooltips
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Go to https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/images/image-upload/image-upload.html
2. Focus the editor and press <kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>F10</kbd> to navigate to the toolbar
3. Press <kbd>Esc</kbd>.

### âœ”ï¸ Expected result

The focus is moved back to the editor.

### âŒ Actual result

The first press of <kbd>Esc</kbd> hides the tooltip, the second one moves the focus. Additionally, this behavior could be even more confusing for the screen reader users as tooltips are not exposed in the accessibility tree.


https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c886e998-e41d-49c5-8251-b024bd9a30bc


### â“ Possible solution

The easiest fix is to remove the current <kbd>Esc</kbd> behavior for tooltips. However, if we need such a behavior for some reason, we'll have to expose tooltips to screen readers using the [`tooltip` role](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Reference/Roles/tooltip_role).


## ğŸ“ƒ Other details

* Browser: Chrome 134.0.6998.166
* OS: macOS 15.4
* First affected CKEditor version: 44.3.0
* Installed CKEditor plugins: N/A

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The tooltip used in CKEditorâ€™s toolbar is not exposed to assistive technologies because it lacks an appropriate ARIA role and accessible name. When a user navigates the toolbar with the keyboard, pressing <kbd>Esc</kbd> first hides the tooltip and only then returns focus to the editor, requiring a second keystroke. This doubleâ€‘press behavior is unintuitive, breaks expected keyboard flow, and prevents screenâ€‘reader users from hearing the tooltip content.
thread_tldr: A user reported that pressing Escape once hides a CKEditor tooltip and pressing it again moves focus back to the editor, which can confuse screenâ€‘reader users because tooltips are not exposed in the accessibility tree. No further discussion or resolution has been recorded.
thread_problem: The CKEditor instance hides a tooltip when Escape is pressed but does not return focus to the editor until Escape is pressed a second time. Because the tooltip is not exposed to assistive technology, the interaction is confusing for screenâ€‘reader users. No specific WCAG Success Criteria are cited, but the issue involves focus management and accessibility tree exposure.
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
thread_links: - [tooltip role](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Reference/Roles/tooltip_role): MDN documentation explaining the tooltip ARIA role. - [CKEditor image upload documentation](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/images/image-upload/image-upload.html): Reproduction page referenced in the report.

Issue Title: Incorrect keyboard behavior in the "Insert image"
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

1. Open https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/images/image-upload/image-upload.html
2. Focus the editor.
3. Press <kbd>Cmd</kbd>+<kbd>F10</kbd> and navigate to the "Insert image" menu button.
4. Press <kbd>space</kbd> to open the menu.
5. Try to navigate the menu with arrow keys.

### âœ”ï¸ Expected result

Arrow keys move the focus between menu items.

### âŒ Actual result

Arrow keys don't move the focus, the <kbd>Tab</kbd> key must be used instead.

### â“ Possible solution

Probably the easiest fix would be to change the dropdown from a `form`-based one to one based on `div[role=menu]` one and update the keyboard navigation to match other `[role=menu]`s in the editor

* OS: macOS 15.4

* Installed CKEditor plugins: `image`

---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The "Insert image" dropdown menu fails to support arrowâ€‘key navigation, requiring users to use Tab instead. This prevents keyboardâ€‘only users and those relying on assistive technologies from accessing menu items in a predictable sequence, impairing operability and user experience.
thread_tldr: The issue reports that the â€œInsert imageâ€ dropdown in CKEditor 5 does not allow navigation with arrow keys, requiring Tab instead, creating a keyboardâ€‘only navigation barrier. No discussion or resolution has been recorded; the issue remains unaddressed.
thread_problem: In CKEditor 5, the â€œInsert imageâ€ dropdown fails to support arrow key navigation, preventing keyboardâ€‘only users from moving focus between menu items. This violates WCAGâ€¯2.2 Levelâ€¯AA success criteria for keyboard accessibility (e.g., 2.1.1 Keyboard, 3.2.1 On Focus, 3.3.2 Keyboard Accessible).

Issue Title: Toolbar buttons in CKEditor 5 do not meet WCAG minimum size requirements (24x24px)
Description: ## ğŸ“ Provide a description of the improvement According to [WCAG 2.5.5 Target Size (Level AA)](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/target-size.html), interactive elements such as buttons should have a minimum target size of 24 by 24 pixels to ensure accessibility for all users, particularly those using touch devices or with motor impairments. When using CKEditor 5 (as integrated in Drupal 10), accessibility auditing tools such as Siteimprove flag toolbar buttons â€” especially split buttons like Numbered List or Bulleted List â€” as too small. --- If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The toolbar buttons in CKEditorâ€¯5 appear too small for touch interaction, making it difficult for users with motor impairments or on touchâ€‘enabled devices to tap them reliably. The reduced target size can lead to selection errors, frustration, and decreased usability.
thread_tldr: Toolbar buttons in CKEditorâ€¯5, specifically split buttons such as Numbered List or Bulleted List, are smaller than the 24â€¯Ã—â€¯24â€¯px target size required by WCAGâ€¯2.2, and the issue has no subsequent discussion or resolution recorded.
thread_problem: The toolbar buttons in CKEditorâ€¯5 fail to meet WCAGâ€¯2.2 Success Criterionâ€¯2.5.5 Target Size, which requires interactive elements to have a minimum target size of 24â€¯Ã—â€¯24â€¯px for users with touch or motor impairments.
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
thread_links: - [WCAG 2.2 Success Criterionâ€¯2.5.5 Target Size](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/target-size.html): The target size requirement that the toolbar buttons fail to meet.

Issue Title: Keyboard support for dragging special characters dialog
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide detailed reproduction steps (if any)

There is no accessibility documentation to move the special characters dialog with the keyboard

1. open accessibility help (alt+0)
2. observe no directions to move or drag the dialog with only the keyboard

### âœ”ï¸ Expected result

As a keyboard user I would expect some kind of focus or keyboard indication that a non-modal window like special characters can be moved so rich text content is not obscured by the dialog.

### âŒ Actual result

There is no documented keystroke to move this dialog with the keyboard. Sighted keyboard-only users must close the special characters dialog if it obscures text while opened.

### â“ Possible solution

At a minimum navigate to the parent container (that contains the ARIA role=dialog) and move the dialog container with the keyboard

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details
tested with CKEditor5 v44.2.0
Browser: Chrome and Safari
OS: Windows 10 and MacOS v13
First affected CKEditor version: the version that changed the special characters from a dropdown component to a non-modal dialog


---

If you'd like to see this fixed sooner, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The specialâ€‘characters panel is presented as a nonâ€‘modal dialog that can cover editable content. Keyboard users cannot reposition or dismiss it, forcing them to close the dialog to continue working. This prevents access to content behind the dialog and violates the expectation that all interactive controls be operable via keyboard.
thread_tldr: Keyboard users cannot move the special characters dialog with the keyboard because no documented keystroke or focus indicator is provided. The issue remains unaddressed with no subsequent discussion.
thread_problem: The special characters dialog is a nonâ€‘modal window that can obscure content. Keyboardâ€‘only users have no documented way to move or dismiss it, forcing them to close the dialog in order to access the underlying text.
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.

Issue Title: Renumber heading levels in Paste from Office
Description:
## ğŸ“ Provide a description of the improvement

The [Paste from Office feature](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/pasting/paste-from-office.html) retains heading levels where configuration allows. However, accessibility guidelines mean the [default heading levels](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/headings.html#heading-levels) start at `<h2>`. If such a config is applied pasting a Word or Google doc will be converted to a paragraph instead.

Ideally the heading levels should be shifted down a level on paste if `<h1>` is not in use.

Such a request was also suggested in [this comment on #2443](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/2443#issuecomment-321299883).

## ğŸ“ƒ Other details
Related issues:

- #2443
- #2455
- #2479
- #10577


---

If you'd like to see this improvement implemented, add a ğŸ‘ reaction to this post.
acr_note: The pasting behavior removes heading markup when the editorâ€™s configured heading levels begin atâ€¯`<h2>`. As a result, content that originally used headings in source documents is rendered as plain paragraphs, breaking the documentâ€™s logical structure and making it harder for users of assistive technologies to navigate or understand the content hierarchy.
thread_tldr: The issue reports that CKEditorâ€¯5â€™s Paste from Office feature preserves heading levels, but the editorâ€™s default heading hierarchy starts at `<h2>`. Consequently, pasted content from Word or Google Docs that contains `<h1>` headings is converted to paragraphs, breaking semantic structure. No discussion or resolution has been recorded.
thread_problem: When the Paste from Office feature retains heading levels that are not part of the editorâ€™s default heading hierarchy (which starts at `<h2>`), `<h1>` headings from source documents are downgraded to paragraphs. This removal of proper heading structure prevents assistive technology users from correctly navigating document sections, violating WCAGâ€¯2.2 Success Criteriaâ€¯2.4.1 (Headings and Labels) andâ€¯2.4.6 (Headings and Labels).
thread_timeline: #1 reporter: Filed initial accessibility report. No further discussion recorded.
thread_links: - [Paste from Office feature](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/pasting/paste-from-office.html): Description of the feature that preserves heading levels. - [Heading levels](https://ckeditor.com/docs/ckeditor5/latest/features/headings.html#heading-levels): Explanation of CKEditorâ€¯5â€™s default heading hierarchy. - [Comment on #2443](https://github.com/ckeditor/ckeditor5/issues/2443#issuecomment-321299883): Suggestion for shifting heading levels on paste.

Issue Title: Toolbar/Menubar focus keyboard shortcuts are shifting focus when a fullscreen modal/dialog is opened

thread_tldr: A CKEditor 5 featureâ€‘rich demo user reports that pressing `Alt+F9` or `Alt+F10` while a fullscreen modal (e.g., Media Embed) is open moves focus to the toolbar, leaving the modal open and trapping keyboard focus. No resolution or followâ€‘up discussion has been recorded.
thread_problem: When a fullscreen modal or dialog is displayed, the keyboard shortcuts `Alt+F9` and `Alt+F10` intended to focus the menubar or toolbar cause the focus to leave the modal. This focus shift occurs while the modal remains open, preventing the user from returning focus to the modal or closing it via keyboard. The behavior conflicts with WCAGâ€¯2.2 Levelâ€¯AA success criteria that require (1) all interactive functionality to be operable via keyboard (2.1.1) and (2) focus to be managed in a predictable order (2.4.3).
